pageContext.claim: “They ought to take the Pulitzer Prize away from all of these phony journalists that got a Pulitzer Prize. And they -- they were wrong. They were wrong on everything, and now they've been proven wrong.”
pageContext.analysis: The reporting was accurate then and remains accurate now: The Trump campaign knew about Russia's moves to interfere in the 2016 election and welcomed those efforts. The Washington Post and the New York Times were awarded a Pulitzer Prize for their "deeply sourced, relentlessly reported coverage in the public interest that dramatically furthered the nation’s understanding of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and its connections to the Trump campaign, the President-elect’s transition team and his eventual administration." No substantive errors were found in the articles; none has merited corrections. One of them disclosed that Trump drafted his son's misleading statement about a meeting at Trump Tower with a Russian said to offer damaging information on Hillary Clinton.
